posts._title: Andrew L. Stone – The Password Is Courage (1962)
posts.title: The Password Is Courage
posts.excerpt: A British officer, captured by the Germans, tries everything he can to escape. In the process, amongst many other adventures he gets awarded the Iron Cross !! Based on a true story.

posts._title: José Giovanni – Deux hommes dans la ville AKA Two Men in Town (1973)
posts.title: Deux hommes dans la ville
posts.excerpt: Synopsis:Thanks to the support and influence of a kindly parole officer, Gino Strabliggi is released from prison and has a chance to start a new life. However, things soon begin to go wrong for him. First his wife is killed in a car accident and then a ruthless police commissioner, Goitreau, begins to taunt him. …

posts._title: Fernando Vargas – Di buen día a papá AKA Say Good Morning to Dad (2005)
posts.title: Di buen día a papá
posts.excerpt: Quote:This interesting and colorful film has been unseeded for more than five years and deserves an upgrade IMnHO. A Bolivia-Cuba-Argentina coproduction with Ibermedia help and several film institutions, it was the Official submission of Bolivia for the ‘Best Foreign Language Film’ category of the 78th Academy Awards in 2006… not that it matters that much.

posts._title: Maurice Pialat – Passe ton bac d’abord… aka Graduate first (1979)
posts.title: Passe ton bac d’abord…
posts.excerpt: The world sometimes seems divided into two camps: those who recall their teenage years as having been an exhilarating dream, and those who remember them as having been an infernal, nightmarish hell. So it might do to describe Passe ton bac d’abord… [Graduate First… / Pass Your Bac First…] as Maurice Pialat’s “The Best Years …

posts._title: Paul Morrison – Solomon and Gaenor AKA Solomon and Gaenor (1999)
posts.title: Solomon and Gaenor
posts.excerpt: A young Jew in 1911 Wales tries to make his living by selling fabrics door to door, but to do so he must hide his nationality. On one of his sales he meets and falls in love with a demure young woman with a strong-willed father and a Jew-hating brother. The two fall in love …

posts.title: The Fall
posts.excerpt: Quote:Considered by Whitehead to be his most important film, The Fall is an extraordinary piece of filmmaking, an extremely personal statement on violence, revolution and the turbulence within late sixties America. Filmed entirely in and around New York between October 1967 and June 1968, it features Robert Kennedy, The Bread and Puppet Theater, Paul Auster …

posts.title: Eaux d’artifice
posts.excerpt: Quote:A woman dressed elegantly walks purposely through the water gardens at the Villa d’Este in Tivoli, as the music of Vivaldi’s “Winter” movement of “The Four Seasons” plays. Heavy red filters give a blue cast to the light; water plays across stone, and fountains send it into the air. No words are spoken. Baroque statuary …

posts.title: Tortoise Beats Hare
posts.excerpt: An upset Bugs challenges the slick Cecil Turtle to a race.

posts.title: Neds
posts.excerpt: Quote:Encompassed by violent street gangs, neglectful parents, bullying teachers and a dearth of positive role models, a studious but emotionally abandoned kid turns thug.

posts.title: The Unholy Three
posts.excerpt: Lon Chaney — the Man of a Thousand Faces — used his makeup skills, astonishing physicality and profound empathy to create Quasimodo, the Phantom of the Opera and more of the Silent Era’s greatest horror roles. In this hypnotic mix of creepiness and crime, he plays a ventriloquist who dons a granny disguise to team …
